items.title: upAdhi / upAhitam
items.summary: "Upaadhi Upaahitam" is a term used in Vedanta to describe a phenomenon where attributes of one entity appear to be present in another due to their close association or proximity. Upaadhi: The term "Upaadhi" refers to a limiting adjunct or condition that affects or influences…
items.content_html:
"Upaadhi Upaahitam" is a term used in Vedanta to describe a phenomenon where attributes of one entity appear to be present in another due to their close association or proximity.

  1. Upaadhi: The term "Upaadhi" refers to a limiting adjunct or condition that affects or influences something else. In this context, it can represent the mind or any other limited aspect of individual experience.

  2. Upaahitam: "Upaahitam" refers to that which is influenced or affected by the Upaadhi. In this context, it represents consciousness or the underlying substratum of reality.

When we say "Upaadhi Upaahitam," we're describing a situation where the attributes or characteristics of one entity (the Upaadhi) seem to be transferred or projected onto another (the Upaahitam) due to their close association.

For example, when the mind (Upaadhi) is closely associated with consciousness (Upaahitam), the limitations or qualities of the mind may appear to affect consciousness. This can create the illusion that consciousness is limited or conditioned by the attributes of the mind, such as thoughts, emotions, or perceptions.

However, from the perspective of Vedanta, consciousness itself is unaffected by the attributes of the mind. It remains inherently limitless and unaffected by any conditioning. The apparent influence of the mind on consciousness is seen as a result of their close association or proximity, rather than any intrinsic property of consciousness itself.

In summary, "Upaadhi Upaahitam" describes the phenomenon where attributes of one entity seem to affect another due to their close association, highlighting the importance of discerning/ identifying the true nature of reality beyond apparent limitations or conditioning.

items.title: Chitrapata Nyaya
items.summary: "Chitrapata Nyaya" is an analogy used in Vedanta, to illustrate the concept of Maya, the illusion of the world. In this analogy, the example given is of a cloth with various designs like mountains, sun, etc., woven into it. However, upon closer examination, one realizes…
items.content_html:
"Chitrapata Nyaya" is an analogy used in Vedanta, to illustrate the concept of Maya, the illusion of the world.

In this analogy, the example given is of a cloth with various designs like mountains, sun, etc., woven into it. However, upon closer examination, one realizes that the cloth is made up only of threads arranged in a particular manner (long threads and cross threads). If one were to pull a single thread, the entire cloth would unravel, and what remains is just a ball of thread. The mountains, sun, and other designs were never inherent in the cloth itself; they were merely woven into it. In reality, only the threads exist.

Similarly, according to this analogy, the world as we perceive it—earth, sky, mountains, sun, and all other objects—is like the designs on the cloth. These are merely names and forms woven into the fabric of consciousness. When we delve deeper into the nature of reality, we realize that these forms are not inherent in the underlying substrate but are superimposed upon it. Just as pulling a thread reveals the true nature of the cloth, the realization of the underlying consciousness unveils the true nature of reality, where names and forms dissolve, leaving only the essence of existence.

Kapde par suraj pahaad wagera banaa hua hai.. but kapda actual me sirf threads ka (ot = long thread prot= cross thread)  arrangement he hai.. agar ek thread pakad ke kheech Diya to poora kapdaa udhad jaayega aur udhade huwe dhaage ka golaa banaa ke side me rakh do.. ab wo suraj pahaad bhi jo kapde ke bane huwe they gayab hogaye. Na suraj tha na pahaad aur na he kapda… thread alone was reality
Similarly earth sky etc are name and form woven into consciousness

items.title: Abhidhaana & Abhidheya
items.summary: In Vedanta, the terms "abhidhaana" and "abhidheya" refer to fundamental concepts concerning language and its relationship to reality. Abhidhaana (the word): Abhidhaana represents the word itself, the linguistic sign or symbol that is used to convey meaning. It's the spoken or written form of language,…
items.content_html:
In Vedanta, the terms "abhidhaana" and "abhidheya" refer to fundamental concepts concerning language and its relationship to reality.

Abhidhaana (the word): Abhidhaana represents the word itself, the linguistic sign or symbol that is used to convey meaning. It's the spoken or written form of language, such as individual words, phrases, or sentences. Abhidhaana is the medium through which communication takes place, enabling us to express ideas, concepts, and experiences.

Abhidheya (the object revealed by the word): Abhidheya refers to the object or meaning conveyed by the word. It's what the word signifies or represents in the mind of the speaker or listener. When we use language, the intention is to convey certain meanings or concepts through words. These meanings or concepts are the abhidheya. They can range from concrete objects and qualities to abstract ideas and philosophical principles.
In summary, abhidhaana is the word itself, while abhidheya is the object or meaning conveyed by the word.

items.title: Limitation of Vaga
items.summary: Limitation of words, or "Vaga," refers to the constraints of language in expressing certain aspects of reality. Words are powerful tools for communication, but they have their limitations. Adi Shankara says words can only reveal four specific aspects: Jaati: This refers to the classification or…
items.content_html:
Limitation of words, or "Vaga," refers to the constraints of language in expressing certain aspects of reality. Words are powerful tools for communication, but they have their limitations. Adi Shankara says words can only reveal four specific aspects:

Jaati: This refers to the classification or category of a thing. Words can label or classify objects based on their type or category. For example, words can distinguish between different species of animals or types of objects.
Guna: Guna refers to the qualities or attributes of a thing. Words can describe the characteristics or properties of objects, such as their color, size, shape, or texture. By using words, we can convey information about the qualities of things.
Kriya: Kriya pertains to the actions or activities associated with a thing. Words can describe the actions performed by objects or individuals. They can convey information about what something does or how it behaves.
Sambandha: Sambandha refers to the relationship or connection between things. Words can describe the relationships between objects or entities, such as cause and effect, association, or dependency. They can convey information about how things are related to each other.
"sangya," which refers to the naming or identification of objects, is closely related to "jaati" (classification), as it involves categorizing objects by assigning them names or labels. By naming objects, we establish their identity and distinguish them from others, which is an essential function of language.

items.title: Samaanaadhikaranya
items.summary: Sarvam khalu idam brahm. Words idam and sarvam are in samaanaadhikaranya, in apposition, revealing the same object. Devadatta is a grammarian, where devadatta and grammarian are in samaanaadhikaranya, revealing one and same person. Suppose a person mistakes a rope for a snake, he is told…
items.content_html:
Sarvam khalu idam brahm. Words idam and sarvam are in samaanaadhikaranya, in apposition, revealing the same object. Devadatta is a grammarian, where devadatta and grammarian are in samaanaadhikaranya, revealing one and same person. 
Suppose a person mistakes a rope for a snake, he is told that it is not a snake but a rope. One word (snake) negates itself and reveals the other. This is "badhyam samaanaadhikaranya". 
Idam sarvam brahm - idam sarvam is negated - this is to be understood as badhyam samaanaadhikaranya.  mundak upanishad part 2, page २२

Explaination: 

"Sarvam khalu idam brahm" expresses the Vedantic concept that everything is indeed Brahman. Here, "idam" (this) and "sarvam" (everything) are in "samaanaadhikaranya," a grammatical term indicating they refer to the same object. It's similar to saying "Devadatta is a grammarian," where "Devadatta" and "grammarian" point to the same person.

In the example of mistaking a rope for a snake, when corrected, the word "snake" negates itself and reveals the truth of the object as a rope. This is termed "badhyam samaanaadhikaranya," where one word negates itself and points to another.

Applying this to "idam sarvam brahm," the phrase "idam sarvam" (all this) is negated, indicating that everything is Brahman. This negation operates similarly to the snake being negated to reveal the rope. It's a way of understanding that all that is perceived ultimately points to the singular reality of Brahman.

items.summary: All these mistakes are called adhyasa or superimposition. Shankara explains it simply as atasmin tadbuddhi - "thinking 'this thing' is 'that thing' when it's not 'that thing at all'... Or, seeing something completely different in a locus where some thing else is present"." For example,…
items.content_html:
All these mistakes are called adhyasa or superimposition.

Shankara explains it simply as atasmin tadbuddhi -  "thinking 'this thing' is 'that thing' when it's not 'that thing at all'...

Or, seeing something completely different in a locus where some thing else is present"."

For example, when we see someone's short body and say "I am short," we're putting the body's quality onto ourselves.

Also, when we say "I am happy or sad," we're putting the mind's feelings onto ourselves. That's called dharma adhyasa.

Imagine two people with similar noses; we might think one person's qualities belong to the other, even without knowing them. That's dharmi adhyasa. (the thief superimposed on the pillar).

Then there's shobhana adhyasa,  means superimposition of beauty or goodness over some thing. According to this concept, before we ever like or try to have an object, this is what we do. Unknown to ourselves- we discover some reason, a good reason, for us to have or enjoy or to be associated with that object. The physical manifestation of this can be observed in all walks of life. Each of us consciously or unconsciously tries to improve one’s appeal by becoming more beautiful/ handsome. Empirical studies carried out indifferent countries, across different cultures/ societies have mostly led to following observations: 

  • Products and services sell better if famous people endorse them.
  • Lots of ads use images of beautiful or strong people to make products seem more appealing.
  • Women often do well in jobs where they have to talk to people or sell things.
  • Good-looking people sometimes get treated better in schools or at work, even if they're not doing anything special.
  • And sometimes, good-looking kids might get into less trouble for the same mistakes at home or school.

There's gnyana adhyasa, like mistaking the sunrise for the sun moving.
There's arthAdhyAsa, like mistaking a rope for a snake.

(Perceptually correct factually wrongs - gyaanaadhyaasa)
(Object is mistaken for another object - arthaadhyaasa)

All these are mistakes. When we understand what's really going on, the mistakes disappear, and we see things as they are.

kAryAdhyAsa and kAraNAdhyAsa -  The superimposition of primal ignorance
which is jagat upAdAna kAraNa on brahman is kAraNAdhyAsa.
The superimposition of the world on Brahman due to that primal ignorance is
kAryAdhyAsa.

svarUpAdhyAsa and samsargAdhyAsa- the superimposition of the svarUpa /
the thing-itself on another (a snake on a rope) is svarUpAdhyAsa, whereas the superimposition of the attributes of a thing on another is samsargAdhyAsa eg, the redness of a flower superimposed on crystal.

nirupAdhika and sopAdhika, adhyAsa involve the presence or absence of an "upAdhi," which transfers its attributes to something nearby. In nirupAdhika adhyAsa, the substratum (like a rope) is misunderstood or not clearly perceived, leading to mistaken identities (like mistaking the rope for a snake). This misconception disappears with the knowledge of the substratum.
In sopAdhika adhyAsa, an upAdhi (like a nearby flower) is present, causing the mistaken perception (like seeing a crystal as red). Even if we know the crystal is colorless, as long as the flower is nearby, the mistaken perception persists.


In Vedanta, understanding mostly involves gnyana adhyasa. We're in the dark about things, so knowledge is the light.

items.title: adhyAropa apavAda nyAya
items.summary: adhyAropa refers to the declaration of real differences among the creator, the creation, and the individual selves. apavAda , on the other hand, involves the negation of these differences. Initially, the teaching emphasizes duality, acknowledging the everyday experience of separateness. This stage is akin to teaching a…
items.content_html:
adhyAropa refers to the declaration of real differences among the creator, the creation, and the individual selves.

apavAda , on the other hand, involves the negation of these differences.

Initially, the teaching emphasizes duality, acknowledging the everyday experience of separateness. This stage is akin to teaching a child the alphabet before introducing complex literature.

As the seeker progresses, the scripture gradually reveals that the individual selves are not separate entities from the divine but are inseparable parts of it. This process of negation begins even without the seeker consciously realizing it.

During these stages, the scripture encourages the pursuit of righteousness, wealth, and desires, as mentioned in yesterday's discussion.

Once the student has developed strong reasoning skills, their mind becomes receptive like fertile soil awaiting seeds. Spiritual knowledge (Sravana, Manana, and Nididhyasana) is present in significant measure.

At this juncture, the scripture begins guiding the seeker towards the teachings of liberation. The examination of the worlds becomes increasingly relevant, leading to the gradual revelation of the meaning of the mahAvAkyAs. These teachings unveil the truth that there is no creator other than the Self, no creation other than the Self, and no individual selves other than the Self.

Vedanta expounds the Mahavakyas through various methods, such as the Eka vignyAnEna sarva vignyAna prakriyA by chAndogya , the Pancha Kosha (five sheaths) prakriya in the Taittiriya Upanishad, and the kArya-kArana (cause-effect) prakriya found in many Upanishads. The pinnacle of these teachings lies in the Mandukya Upanishad's exposition of the avastha traya prakriya and the shariira traya prakriya.

All of these teachings rely on the prakriya of adhyAropa-apavAda, sometimes referred to as the method of superimposition and negation (adhyAropa apavAda nyAya)

Indeed, this method represents the aspiration of every teacher and Upanishad—to guide seekers from the realm of apparent duality to the realization of ultimate non-duality.

items.title: The Six Indicators for Vedic Analysis – Shadlingam
items.summary: Determining the main idea behind Vedic or Upanishadic teachings isn't as straightforward as it may seem. The scriptures have a unique way of testing and sometimes seeming to mislead readers. For instance, the same word in different contexts can signify various meanings. "AkAsha" could refer…
items.content_html:
Determining the main idea behind Vedic or Upanishadic teachings isn't as straightforward as it may seem. The scriptures have a unique way of testing and sometimes seeming to mislead readers. For instance, the same word in different contexts can signify various meanings. "AkAsha" could refer to subtle space, gross space, or chaitanya brahman. Those who teach these Upanishadic principles need to grasp at least a basic understanding of six indicators. And as seekers, it's crucial to handle the words of the scriptures and our teachers with the utmost care and reverence they deserve. 

  1. upakrama and upasamhAra: These indicate the introductory and concluding statements of a topic. In modern presentations, it's like stating something at the beginning, explaining it, and reiterating it at the end. If a statement appears both at the beginning and the end of an Upanishad section, it signifies the primary meaning of the topic.
    For instance, the Chandogya Upanishad chapter six starts with the grand declaration (mahA pratijnA) that -
    "if a given statement is mentioned in the beginning of an upaniShad and in its ending, then that is the primary meaning of the topic.".
    This is the upkrama indicator. Similarly, it concludes with the father uddhAlaka AruNee to his son shvEtakEtu is “that AtmA alone is.. That AtmA alone is satyam.. That AtmA Thou Art, shvEtakEu” .
    And this is upasamhAram and thus we understand the advaitam is the central teaching of chAndogya Upanishad.

  2. abhyAsa: This refers to repetition. In a given topic, a point that is REPEATEDLY MENTIONED is the central theme of that topic.  In chAndogya Upanishad, in the end, the son asks the father NINE times to teach him about bramhan or AtmA again and again.. Then the father ALSO gives NINE different examples to drive home the truth of advaitam into the buddhi of the totally eager, attentive and respectful son. This repetition shows that the central teaching of chAndogya Upanishad is advaitam ONLY.

  3. apoorvata: It points to uniqueness, something not mentioned before. In the Chandogya Upanishad, when the father reveals to his son, Shvetaketu, "You are That Brahman," it unveils a unique understanding previously unknown to Shvetaketu, akin to most of us new to Vedanta, and this unique mahAvAkya we understand to be the central teaching of chAndogya Upanishad.

  4. phalam: This means “what is the USE of even studying this upanishad?” In chAndogya Upanishad, the father tells him that “you know one thing called bramhan, then you AS IF know everything.. and knowing that you end samsara, which is nothing but another name for sorrow”  So shvEtakEtu understands that there is a PREVIOUSLY UNKOWN ADVANTAGE for understanding bramhan.  That is the fruit of advaita vedAntic study mentioned in chAndogya Upanishad 

  5. arthavAda: phalam means “what is the USE of even studying this upanishad?” In chAndogya Upanishad, the father tells him that “you know one thing called bramhan, then you AS IF know everything.. and knowing that you end samsara, which is nothing but another name for sorrow”  So shvEtakEtu understands that there is a PREVIOUSLY UNKOWN ADVANTAGE for understanding bramhan.  That is the fruit of advaita vedAntic study mentioned in chAndogya Upanishad 

  6. upapatti:  upapatti means LOGIC. chAndogya Upanishad uses several examples to teach shvEtakEtu. An example means logic.  Because every example has a PURPOSE which can not be directly imbibed, but only by an less powerful example than the intrinsic truth.  THIS IS NOT A DEFICIENCY OF USING AN EXAMPLE, BUT ACTUALLY THE PURPOSE OF USING AN EXAMPLE TO UNDERSTAND SOMETHING LOFTIER. 
    When we say  9 = 9, is not an example, because there is NOTHING conveyed by such an equation.  And if we say 9 = 8, it is called apadruShTaanta or incorrect example because they can not be equated at all. 
    But if the teacher says 5+4 = 10-1, then the example becomes ALIVE. The terms on the left side appear to be different from the terms on the right side. The plus and minus symbols are different.  STILL THEY ARE EQUATED.  Similarly, tat tvam asi being the mahAvAkya advaita upadEsha of chAndogya Upanishad, we do not understand how this miserable jiva can be THAT bramhan?  shvEtakEtu that is why askes repeatedly to be taught, and every example used by the father to teach his son convinces the student that what the father is teaching HAS TO BE CORRECT.


    Thus these six lingas are used in chAndogya Upanishad and it is a complete Upanishad.  However, just because other Upanishads do not use all the six indicators, it does not mean that they are less in value compared to chAndogya Upanishad.  AN UPANISHAD IS GIVEN THAT NAME ONLY BECAUSE IT EXPOUNDS THE MAHAVAKYA, WHICH IS JEEVA BRAMHA ONENESS.  Other Upanishads may use any number of these indicators, but they will always be focused on mahavakya upadesha.
